content: The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Improvement Act of 1994 amends the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act to include cooperative programs with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. It also addresses the membership of the Board of Directors of the Foundation. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to require consultation with the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere before appointing any Director of the Board. The Board is also expanded from nine to fifteen members, with the number of appointed directors increased from three to four. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to increase the number of appointed directors from three to four. The initial terms of the directors vary from 2 to 6 years, as specified by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary must appoint additional members to the Board of Directors within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to increase the funding to $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1994-1998. The authority of the Board of Directors is not affected by delays in appointments. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to authorize $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1994 to 1998. This additional funding is separate from any other federal funding available to the Foundation. SEC. 105. CONVEYANCE OF SENECAVILLE NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY. The Secretary of the Interior shall convey the Senecaville National Fish Hatchery to the State of Ohio for use in the Ohio fishery resources management program. The conveyance includes all property, easements, water rights, land, improvements, and related personal property. Reversionary interest to the United States applies if the property is not used as specified. The United States retains reversionary interest if the property is not used for the Ohio fishery resources management program. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center is established under Title II. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1994 establishes the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas. The Center, operated by the Port of Brownsville and administered by the University of Texas at Brownsville, aims to utilize the unique wetlands property at the port. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1994 establishes the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas. The Center focuses on protecting, restoring, and maintaining the Lagoon Ecosystems of the Western Gulf of Mexico Region. It is governed by a Board of Directors cochaired by the Port of Brownsville, the University of Texas at Brownsville, and the designee of the Director of the Fish and Wildlife Service. The Board prepares annual reports for submission to Congress. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1994 establishes the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas, focusing on protecting, restoring, and maintaining Lagoon Ecosystems in the Western Gulf of Mexico Region. The Center's Board of Directors prepares annual reports covering programs, projects, activities, accomplishments, and budget details, with all pertinent information made available for report preparation. The Comptroller General of the United States submits periodic reports on the Center's operations to Congress. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1994 establishes the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service can make grants to the Center for its activities. The Director may also enter into a long-term lease with the Port of Brownsville for wetlands property use. Other requirements are outlined in the Act. The University of Texas at Brownsville and the Port of Brownsville are required to provide administrative and classroom space, in-kind contributions, and up to 7,000 acres of Port Property for the programs of the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center. The Board of Directors must report annually on whether these conditions have been met. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations totaling $13,000,000 for fiscal years 1994-1997 is granted to the Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service for grants to the Center. Funds cannot be used to relocate administrative operations from Corpus Christi to the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center. TITLE III_WALTER B. JONES CENTER FOR THE SOUNDS AT THE POCOSIN LAKES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE - SEC. 301. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that the Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern North Carolina lacks an educational center for visitors. A partnership is proposed to establish the Center for the Sounds, which would bring economic benefits to Tyrrell County and Columbia. The Federal Government designated the Albemarle-Pamlico estuary system in northeastern North Carolina as an estuary of national concern. Walter B. Jones supported the establishment and expansion of National Wildlife Refuges in eastern North Carolina, including the Alligator River and Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuges. Jones increased refuge acreage by over 303,000 acres in his district. Walter B. Jones supported the reintroduction of endangered red wolves at Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge and dedicated his congressional career to fish and wildlife conservation. He should be honored by naming the Center for the Sounds at Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge System after him. The Secretary of the Interior may construct and operate the "Walter B. Jones Center for the Sounds" at Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge in North Carolina for public study, environmental education, wildlife awareness, and refuge administration. The Secretary of the Interior will ensure that the design, size, and location of the facility are in line with the area's cultural and natural history. Contributions from non-Federal sources can be accepted to cover operating costs, and a report on progress must be submitted to Congress within 6 months.
